- Nagaenthran a/l K. Dharmalingam, an ethnic Indian Malaysian, was born in Ipoh on 13 September 1988.
- He was the second of four children and had two younger brothers and an elder sister.
- Nagaenthran's father died during his death row imprisonment in Singapore.
- He completed his secondary school education at age 17 and worked at a factory before moving to Singapore for employment.
- Nagaenthran was arrested on 22 April 2009 at the Woodlands Checkpoint for carrying 42.72g of diamorphine.
- He confessed to carrying the drugs for a Chinese friend named "King" to pay off debts and his father's heart surgery fees.
- Nagaenthran later retracted his confession and claimed that King had threatened to kill his girlfriend.
- He was found guilty of drug trafficking and sentenced to death by hanging on 22 November 2010.
- His appeal was dismissed on 27 July 2011 by the Court of Appeal.
- In July 2012, Singapore amended its death penalty laws, empowering judges with the discretion to sentence a drug trafficker to life imprisonment with caning not less than 15 strokes instead of death if the offender is merely a courier and has provided substantive assistance to the narcotics police.
- Another alternative condition to receive life imprisonment is diminished responsibility; had any mental illnesses been diagnosed and found to have substantially impaired one's mental faculties, the offender would have been ineligible for the death sentence and caning would also not be given.
- Nagaenthran applied for re-sentencing in January 2013 on account of clinical intellectual disability and mental illness. His case was sent back to the original trial judge Chan Seng Onn for review in the High Court.

- In 2013, new death penalty laws in Singapore allowed judges to sentence drug traffickers to life imprisonment with caning if they were merely couriers and helped disrupt drug trafficking activities or had diminished responsibility due to mental illness.
- Nagaenthran, diagnosed with low IQ, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, and impaired executive functioning, applied for re-sentencing but was denied in 2015 and 2017, as psychiatrists found no evidence of intellectual disability or mental illness.
- Nagaenthran was not issued a certificate of substantive assistance by the Central Narcotics Bureau, and the High Court found he manipulated and evaded authorities during his offense.
- Nagaenthran filed two appeals to the Court of Appeal in 2018, but they were dismissed in May 2019 due to inconsistencies in his account, which affected his credibility.
- Judges determined Nagaenthran's mental responsibility for his offense was not substantially impaired, and he was able to weigh the concept of right or wrong.
- Nagaenthran appealed to the President of Singapore for clemency in 2020, but it was rejected, finalizing his death sentence.
- The last time clemency was granted in Singapore was in 1998.

- In response to the increasing rate of abuses of court processes in capital cases, the government passed the Post-Appeal Applications in Capital Cases Bill, which imposes stringent regulations on the filing of post-appeal applications.
- Only the Court of Appeal can grant a stay of execution for a prisoner awaiting capital punishment, and a single judge would be appointed to hear the cases before deciding whether to postpone the inmate's execution.
- If a prisoner is found to have abused court processes, he will be prohibited from making a post-appeal application unless there is new evidence.
- The law was supported by most, including Pritam Singh, but criticized by Human Rights Watch for cutting off inmates' chances to oppose their execution and access to last chances of justice.
